title: 108_s2235
content: The "Domestic Workforce Protection Act" renames the Department of Commerce to the Department of Trade and Commerce. Any references to the Department of Commerce in existing laws will now refer to the Department of Trade and Commerce. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to transfer the Office of the United States Trade Representative to the Department of Trade and Commerce. Additionally, deferral to eliminate tax benefits for offshore production is terminated. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to transfer the Office of the United States Trade Representative to the Department of Trade and Commerce. Section 951(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to terminate deferral of tax benefits for offshore production. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to transfer the Office of the United States Trade Representative to the Department of Trade and Commerce. Section 951(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to terminate deferral of tax benefits for offshore production. SEC. 956A addresses the earnings of controlled foreign corporations. The amount determined for any controlled foreign corporation with respect to a United States shareholder is the lesser of the shareholder's pro rata share of the corporation's assets over earnings and profits, or the shareholder's pro rata share of applicable earnings after certain adjustments. The term "applicable earnings" for a controlled foreign corporation is the sum of earnings accumulated after February 29, 2004, reduced by distributions and certain earnings and profits. If a foreign corporation ceases to be controlled during a taxable year, the determination of a US shareholder's share is based on owned stock. The pro rata share of a shareholder in a controlled foreign corporation is based on the stock owned on the last day of the taxable year. The corporation's assets are determined only up to that last day, and applicable earnings are allocated on a pro rata basis during the period when the corporation is controlled. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to implement this section. The text discusses regulations to prevent avoidance of tax provisions and amendments to the previously taxed income rules under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address the inclusion of earnings under specific subparagraphs. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include earnings from specific subparagraphs for taxable years of foreign corporations beginning after February 29, 2004. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include earnings from specific subparagraphs for taxable years of foreign corporations beginning after February 29, 2004. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to submit technical and conforming changes to reflect the new provisions to the relevant committees within 90 days of enactment. SEC. 5. DISALLOWANCE OF DEDUCTIONS FOR CERTAIN OFFSHORE ROYALTY PAYMENTS. This section adds a new provision to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding certain offshore royalty payments. SEC. 280I prohibits deductions for offshore royalty payments to affiliated entities outside the US for copyrighted or trademarked products, unless a valid business reason is proven. SEC. 7625 increases the IRS authority to prevent corporations from using tax havens. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. The IRS is authorized to prevent corporations from using tax havens by denying deductions or credits, reallocating income, and disregarding transactions. A tax haven is defined as a country meeting OECD criteria. SEC. 7. Assistant Attorney General for Trade. The Attorney General appoints an Assistant Attorney General for Trade to investigate anticompetitive conduct by foreign companies impacting the US economy and global competitiveness. This includes violations of international trade agreements and taking appropriate action against them. The Assistant Attorney General for Trade investigates and takes action against activities worldwide that harm the US economy and global competitiveness. This authority is in addition to other enforcement agencies. SEC. 8. The Secretary of Homeland Security will hire 1,000 customs agents to prevent illegal transshipments of textiles. SEC. 9. Aiming to increase domestic production of critical goods for national defense. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with other key departments, will develop a program to boost domestic production of essential goods for national security. The program will be implemented through existing programs, with a report to Congress due within 18 months. The Secretary of Commerce will develop a program to boost domestic production of essential goods for national security. The Secretary may submit a report with recommendations to Congress, and funds will be appropriated as necessary for the program. The Senate urges Congress to fully fund the Regional Centers for the Transfer of Manufacturing Technology program and the Advanced Technology Program. The United States International Trade Commission is abolished and its functions are transferred to the Department of Commerce. The Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Import Administration will now perform these functions. The Office of Management and Budget will determine the functions transferred under this section. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, will determine the transfers and make necessary dispositions of personnel, assets, liabilities, grants, contracts, and funds to carry out the Act. Termination of entities and further measures will be taken to achieve the Act's purposes.
